title: Jesus Christ, as creator
comment: Scripture identifies the pre-existent Jesus Christ as involved in the work of creation, and relates this to his work in redemption, by which a new creation is brought out of the ruins of the old.

children.title: Jesus Christ, as high priest
children.comment: Jesus Christ, being a truly human high priest, perfectly represents humanity before God. He made atonement for sins by his own sacrificial death. Being a truly divine high priest, this act of Christ's was perfect, once for all and of eternal value.

children.title: The ministry of Jesus Christ as high priest
He made atonement for sin
He represents human beings before God
He entered the Most Holy Place

primaryrefs.comment: On the Day of Atonement the high priest entered the Most Holy Place (the sanctuary) which represented the presence of God. Jesus Christ fulfilled this ritual by entering heaven.

children.title: He makes believers perfect
He brings believers close to God
He helps those being tempted
He intercedes continually
Jesus Christ, the human high priest
As a man he is able to represent human beings
He is divinely appointed
Jesus Christ, the divine high priest
He is sinless

primaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ is strongly contrasted with other high priests because he did not have to offer sacrifices for his own sins.

children.title: He is eternal
His atoning work was completed once for all

primaryrefs.comment: Other high priests had to repeat their sacrifices.

children.title: He is exalted
Jesus Christ's high priesthood was of the order of Melchizedek

primaryrefs.comment: The priesthood of Melchizedek resembles that of Jesus Christ because he too was king and had neither beginning nor end.

children.title: Responses to Jesus Christ's high priesthood

secondaryrefs.comment: a call to keep to the faith
an invitation to seek God's help in times of need
an invitation to draw near to God
a call to run the race of faith
a call to offer thanksgiving and worship

children.title: Jesus Christ, as judge
children.comment: Jesus Christ executed judgment against the forces of evil through his death on the cross. Individuals will be judged according to their response to his saving grace.

children.title: Jesus Christ is appointed judge by God the Father
Jesus Christ is a just judge
Jesus Christ's death brought judgment on Satan and evil world powers
Jesus Christ will act as judge at the end of time
People will be judged according to their response to Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ's teaching on judgment
Jesus Christ will separate the righteous from the unrighteous

seealsos.comment: the parable of the sheep and the goats

children.title: Those who reject Jesus Christ will be punished
Christians will stand before Jesus Christ as judge and be rewarded for what they have done

seealsos.comment: the parable of the ten minas

children.title: The day of Jesus Christ's return as judge is unknown

seealsos.comment: the parable of the ten virgins

children.title: Jesus Christ, as king
children.comment: Jesus Christ is declared king at his birth: he descends from the royal line of David. People rejected his kingly claims at his crucifixion but God exalted him to his rightful place of power and majesty. At the end of time Jesus Christ will rule the nations for ever.

children.title: Jesus Christ descends from the royal line of David
He was the Son of David

primaryrefs.comment: The Messiah was expected to come from David's line. The genealogy given by Matthew follows the royal line of the kings descended from David.

children.title: He was born in Bethlehem, the town of David
Jesus Christ is regarded as king

primaryrefs.comment: By Nathanael.

children.title: Jesus Christ refused worldly kingdoms
Jesus Christ entered Jerusalem as a king
Jesus Christ's kingship is an issue at his trial
Pilate questions Jesus Christ

primaryrefs.comment: Pilate's first words to Jesus Christ are the same in all the Gospels.

children.title: Jesus Christ claims to be a spiritual king
Pilate appeals to the crowd to accept Jesus Christ as their king
The crowd reject Jesus Christ as king
Jesus Christ is mocked as king
Jesus Christ is declared king at his crucifixion

primaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ's claim to be king was the ``crime'' for which he was executed.

children.title: God has exalted Jesus Christ to his rightful place as king
As king, Jesus Christ welcomes believers into his kingdom
Jesus Christ is king of all kings
He will rule over the nations
He is king for ever
Jesus Christ, as Lamb
children.comment: Jesus Christ is referred to as the ``Lamb of God''. This symbol points to Christ being a perfect sacrifice for sin. It also conveys his meekness and his willingness to submit to suffering and death.

children.title: The imagery of the lamb
An image of innocence and attraction
An image of submissiveness and vulnerability
An image of quiet suffering
An image of sacrifice

primaryrefs.comment: ``each day'' here refers to the seven-day period of the consecration of priests.

children.title: Jesus Christ is likened to a lamb
The symbolism of the lamb applies to Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ is innocent and draws people to himself
Jesus Christ was submissive and vulnerable
Jesus Christ suffered quietly
Jesus Christ is seen as a sacrifice
Jesus Christ as the glorious Lamb in the book of Revelation
The Lamb is worthy
The Lamb is upon the throne
The Lamb will execute judgment
The Lamb is the bridegroom of the church
Jesus Christ, as prophet
children.comment: Jesus Christ was acclaimed as a prophet by those who witnessed his miracles and heard his teaching. They recognised him as a bearer of the word of God, who spoke with authority concerning the nature and purposes of God.

children.title: Examples of those who recognised Jesus Christ as a prophet
People anticipating the coming prophet

primaryrefs.comment: The reference is to the promised prophet, who, like Moses, would see God face to face (see Dt 18:15,18).

children.title: A Samaritan woman
Witnesses of Jesus Christ's miracles
The crowd as Jesus Christ approached Jerusalem
Two of Jesus Christ's disciples after his death
The apostles Peter and Stephen
Indications of Jesus Christ being a prophet
He announced coming blessing from God
He announced coming judgment and woe
He possessed supernatural knowledge and insight
He performed mighty works and miracles
Jesus Christ's own understanding of himself as a prophet
As a rejected prophet
As a prophet anointed by God's Spirit
As a prophet who speaks with authority
The place of Jesus Christ in relation to other prophets
Jesus Christ is greater than other prophets

seealsos.comment: John the Baptist was accepted as a prophet (e.g., Mt 11:9).

children.title: Jesus Christ is the Messiah and Son of God
The exalted Christ is the source and essence of all prophecy
Jesus Christ, as redeemer
children.comment: Jesus Christ redeems believers from all forms of sinful bondage and oppression through his death and resurrection. The price of that redemption, his own death, represents a ransom paid to secure the freedom of those held in bondage to sin.

children.title: The incarnate God as redeemer
God as redeemer
Jesus Christ as redeemer
Forms of bondage from which Jesus Christ redeems believers
Jesus Christ redeems from slavery to sin
Jesus Christ redeems from the curse of the law
Jesus Christ redeems from empty religion
Jesus Christ redeems from the power of Satan
Jesus Christ redeems from the coming judgment
Jesus Christ redeems from death
The means by which Jesus Christ has redeemed believers
Redemption comes through the incarnation of Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ redeems by his sacrificial death
Jesus Christ redeems by paying a ransom
The purposes for which Jesus Christ redeems believers
Jesus Christ redeems believers so that their sins may be forgiven
Jesus Christ redeems believers to make them pure
Jesus Christ redeems believers so that they may receive God's promised blessings
Jesus Christ redeems believers so that they may receive final redemption
Jesus Christ, as Saviour
children.comment: God's work of salvation is accomplished supremely through the cross and resurrection of Jesus Christ. Through faith, the believer is able to share in all the saving benefits won by Jesus Christ through his obedience to God.

children.title: Jesus Christ is the Saviour
Jesus Christ is called Saviour
Jesus Christ is the promised Saviour
Jesus Christ's purpose is to save
Jesus Christ's qualities as Saviour
Jesus Christ is the unique Saviour
Jesus Christ is the complete Saviour
Jesus Christ is the Saviour of the world
Jesus Christ saves through his grace
Jesus Christ saves by his mighty acts
Jesus Christ saves by his death
Jesus Christ saves by his resurrection life
Jesus Christ saves by his coming again
Jesus Christ saves by defeating Satan
Jesus Christ saves from all forms of evil
Jesus Christ saves from physical danger
Jesus Christ saves from the power of sin
Jesus Christ saves from the condemnation of law
Jesus Christ saves from God's wrath
Jesus Christ saves from the power of death
Jesus Christ saves from Satan's power
Jesus Christ saves to bring people to God
Jesus Christ saves for eternal life
Jesus Christ saves so that people may live for God
Jesus Christ's salvation is received through faith
Jesus Christ, as servant
children.comment: Jesus Christ laid aside his majesty in order to serve humanity. His death is the supreme example of his servanthood: the fulfilling of the will of God his Father.

children.title: The prophets speak of the Messiah as a servant
Jesus Christ describes himself as a servant
Jesus Christ acts as a servant
By coming to dwell among humanity as a man
By obeying God's will
By ministering to his disciples
By dying on the cross
The exaltation of Jesus Christ the servant
He will complete his task
He will be exalted by God
Jesus Christ's obedience and servanthood an example to believers
Jesus Christ, as shepherd
children.comment: A title for Jesus Christ indicating believers' dependence on him as he protects, tends and guides those whom he knows intimately.

children.title: Prophecies about the shepherd Messiah
Jesus Christ's role as the good shepherd
He has compassion for the helpless
He seeks lost sheep
He knows his own sheep
His sheep know his voice
He provides for and protects his sheep
He lays down his life for his sheep
He judges the sheep
Jesus Christ shepherds his flock
Christians are Jesus Christ's flock
Under-shepherds are appointed over Jesus Christ's flock
Jesus Christ the risen Lord is Shepherd
Jesus Christ, attitude to OT
children.comment: Jesus Christ's teaching was based largely on the OT, which he treated as God's inspired and authoritative word, but which he had the authority to interpret.

children.title: Jesus Christ recognises the OT as Scripture
Jesus Christ calls the OT ``Scripture''
Jesus Christ underlines the authority of the OT
The OT is authoritative over Jesus Christ's opponents
The OT is authoritative over Satan
Jesus Christ regards the OT as being fulfilled in himself
Jesus Christ regards his ministry as fulfilling the OT
Jesus Christ regards his death as fulfilling OT prophecy
Other aspects of the OT fulfilled or affirmed by Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ confirms the OT teaching about judgment
Jesus Christ interprets OT teaching
Jesus Christ interprets OT teaching about the Sabbath
Jesus Christ interprets OT teaching about religious practices
Jesus Christ interprets OT teaching about purity
Jesus Christ interprets OT teaching about family life
Jesus Christ interprets OT teaching about retaliation
Jesus Christ refers to the OT in his teaching
Jesus Christ uses the language of the OT
Jesus Christ appeals to the OT in its entirety

primaryrefs.comment: The murders of Abel and Zechariah occur in the first (Ge 4:8) and last (2Ch 24:21) books of the Hebrew OT (Chronicles comes at the close of the OT according to the Hebrew arrangement).

seealsos.comment: The Law, the Prophets and the Psalms are the three divisions of the Hebrew OT.

children.title: Jesus Christ treats the OT as a true historical record
Jesus Christ, exaltation of
children.comment: Having completed his work on earth, Jesus Christ is raised to God's right hand where he receives honour, power and glory.

children.title: Jesus Christ is exalted to God's right hand

primaryrefs.comment: God's right hand is the position of authority second only to the Father.

children.title: Jesus Christ is exalted because he first humbled himself
Jesus Christ's exaltation follows his resurrection and ascension
Jesus Christ's exaltation is predicted in the OT
As God's servant

primaryrefs.comment: This ``servant'' is a specific prediction of Jesus Christ.

children.title: Jesus Christ is exalted by God the Father
The work of the exalted Christ
As Saviour
As high priest and advocate
In giving the Holy Spirit and spiritual gifts to his people
In making every authority subject to him
Believers should lead lives that are mindful of Jesus Christ's exaltation
Believers are exalted with Jesus Christ
Believers should be concerned with heavenly values
Jesus Christ, example of
children.comment: Jesus Christ sets his disciples an example, especially in servanthood, self-denial and endurance of suffering, so that they may become like him.

children.title: Jesus Christ calls believers to follow his example
The qualities of Jesus Christ which set an example for believers
Self-denial
Endurance of suffering
Service
Faithfulness
Love
Patience
Forgiveness of others
Gentleness and humility
Purity
Prayer
God wants his people to follow Jesus Christ's example and be conformed to his image

secondaryrefs.comment: Stephen is following the example set by Jesus Christ in Lk 23:34.

children.title: Jesus Christ, Holy Spirit in life of
Jesus Christ, kingdom of
children.comment: The present and future realm in which Jesus Christ exercises full authority, and through which he triumphs over all opposition.

children.title: Jesus Christ's kingdom is a heavenly kingdom
It is not of this world
The kingdom was given to him by God
The kingdom is his by right
Jesus Christ inherits the kingdom promised to David
Jesus Christ reveals God's kingdom on earth
Jesus Christ brought in God's kingdom

primaryrefs.comment: The expressions ``kingdom of heaven'' and the ``kingdom of God'' are interchangeable.

children.title: Miracles are a sign of the kingdom
Parables are a sign of the kingdom
Jesus Christ exercises kingdom authority today
Believers enter Jesus Christ's kingdom immediately

His kingdom lasts for ever
Jesus Christ, life of
Jesus Christ, miracles of
children.comment: Supernatural acts of Jesus Christ, revealing and confirming his Messianic credentials, and the coming of God's kingdom. The miracles of Christ are to be seen as an integral part of his ministry.

children.title: Examples of the kind of miracles Jesus Christ performed
Authority over natural forces

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ turns water into wine.

children.title: Healing the sick

seealsos.comment: the woman with the issue of blood
the man with a shrivelled hand

children.title: Casting out demons
Raising the dead
The purpose of Jesus Christ's miracles
To bring healing and wholeness
To reveal God's kingdom
To fulfil God's word
To bring glory to God
To show Jesus to be the Messiah
Varying responses to Jesus Christ's miracles
Terror and fear
Wonder and amazement
Faith and gratitude
Opposition and hatred
Limitations on Jesus Christ's miracles
Jesus Christ restricted his miracles because of superficial faith
Miracles require faith
Jesus Christ's miracles performed through others
Through the disciples during Jesus Christ's lifetime
Through the apostles after Jesus Christ's ascension
Through the church
Jesus Christ, mission of
children.comment: The work that Jesus Christ was sent to do, including both his healing and preaching ministry, but particularly his work of salvation. Jesus Christ sends Christians to continue his work by proclaiming his message of salvation.

children.title: Jesus Christ was called to his mission from the beginning of time
Jesus' mission as Messiah was foretold
His mission to help and heal the poor
His mission to rule and establish the kingdom of God
His mission to establish justice and peace
His mission to suffer and die
His mission was fulfilled in humility and poverty
His mission was for all nations
Aspects of Jesus Christ's mission
Preaching and teaching
Sacrificial service
Healing

primaryrefs.comment: A healing ministry was one of the signs of the expected Messiah.

children.title: Judgment

primaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ does not come to condemn, but the response people make to him is the ultimate criterion of judgment. Those truly seeking God turn to faith in Jesus Christ; unbelievers, by their rejection of him, are confirmed in their unbelief.

children.title: Criteria for the direction of Jesus Christ's mission
Obedience to his Father's will
The fulfilment of the Law and the Prophets
Jesus Christ's saving death is the supreme aspect and focus of his mission
Jesus Christ came to save and to give life
Jesus Christ came to suffer and to die
Jesus Christ was aware of the personal cost of his mission
The mission of Jesus Christ continues today
Jesus Christ's own work continues
Christians are called to share in Jesus Christ's mission
Jesus Christ, parables of
children.comment: A central feature of Jesus Christ's teaching was the use of extended similies and short stories about the kingdom of God, based on human experience. Christ used them frequently to call for a response to his message.

children.title: Parables are a central feature of Jesus Christ's teaching
Different characteristics of Jesus Christ's parables
They vary in complexity and length
They vary in their use of metaphors, word pictures, objects and actions
They have different levels of meaning
children.precomment: Often the full impact of a parable may be lost if the Jewish context is not understood:

children.title: They draw on human experience
The themes of Jesus Christ's parables
The kingdom of God
Relationship with God
Right behaviour
The time of the end
Jesus Christ speaks about himself
Understanding Jesus Christ's parables
Further explanation is sometimes needed
The meaning is sometimes hidden

primaryrefs.comment: The meaning of Jesus Christ's parables was concealed only from those whose hearts and minds were closed.

children.title: Responses to Jesus Christ's parables
The parables demand action
Positive responses
Rejection of Jesus Christ and his parables
Examples of Jesus Christ's parables

children.title: Jesus Christ, prayers of
children.comment: Prayer was the essence of Jesus Christ's relationship with the Father. He prayed for himself and his mission, and he continues to pray for all believers.

children.title: Jesus Christ's practice of prayer
He prayed regularly

primaryrefs.comment: Luke records more instances of Jesus Christ praying than any other Gospel writer.

children.comment: A vital feature of Jesus Christ's ministry, focusing on his authoritative proclamation of the kingdom of God.

children.title: Jesus Christ's mission as preaching and teaching
Jesus Christ was regarded as a teacher and prophet

primaryrefs.comment: ``Rabbi'' was an honorific title given to Jesus Christ unofficially by the people.

Jesus Christ, prophecies concerning
children.comment: The OT points ahead to the person and ministry of Jesus Christ. Christ's fulfilment of OT prophecy is often noted by NT writers as a demonstration of God's faithfulness to his promises of salvation and as confirmation of the divine authority of Jesus Christ.

Jesus Christ, victory of
children.comment: Jesus Christ triumphs over and disarms all the powers of evil arrayed against him. Believers are able to share in this victory through faith in Jesus Christ.

Over temptation
Over sin
Over Satan

children.title: Over the world
